revisions.rev:
<!-- Note: The rankings in the Infobox NCAA football single game are the rankings coming INTO this specific game. --> <!-- Note: The records (E.g. 1-0 in the Infobox NCAA football single game are the records coming INTO this specific game. --> {{Infobox NCAA football single game |Name=100th Red River Shootout |date=October 8, 2005 |Year=2005 |Visitor School=University of Oklahoma |Visitor Name Short=Oklahoma |Visitor Nickname=Sooners |Visitor Record=2-2[[2005 Oklahoma vs. Texas football game#Notes and references|â ]] |Visitor AP= |Visitor Coaches= |Visitor BCS= |Visitor Coach=[[Bob Stoops]] |Visitor1=6 |Visitor2=0 |Visitor3=0 |Visitor4=6 |Visitor Total=12 |Home School=University of Texas at Austin |Home Name Short=Texas |Home Nickname=Longhorns |Home Record=4-0 |Home AP=2 |Home Coaches=2 |Home BCS= |Home Coach=[[Mack Brown]] |Home1=14 |Home2=10 |Home3=7 |Home4=14 |Home Total=45 |Type=c |Stadium=[[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]] |City=[[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]], [[Texas]] |Image=[[File:SBC Red River Rivalry 100 year logo.JPG]] |Odds=Texas by 14 |US Network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] }} <!-- Note: The rankings and records in the Infobox NCAA football single game ABOVE are given coming INTO this specific game. -->
{{NCAATeamSeason |Year=2005 |Team=Texas Longhorns |Image= |Conference=Big 12 Conference |Division=South |ShortConference=Big 12 |CoachRank=1 |APRank=1 |BCSRank=1 |Record=13-0 |ConfRecord=9-0 |HeadCoach=[[Mack Brown]] |OffCoach= [[Greg Davis (coach)|Greg Davis]] |DefCoach= [[Gene Chizik]] & [[Duane Akina]] |OScheme= [[Offensive philosophy (American football)#The Spread|Spread Option]] |DScheme= [[4-3]] |StadiumArena=[[Darrell K. Royal-Texas Memorial Stadium]] |Champion=Big 12 Conference, BCS National Champions |BowlTourney=2006 Rose Bowl |BowlTourneyResult=41-38 }}
{{NCAATeamSeason |Year=2005 |Team=Oklahoma Sooners |Image= |Conference=Big 12 Conference |Division=South |ShortConference=Big 12 |CoachRank= |APRank= |Record=8-4[[2005 Oklahoma vs. Texas football game#Notes and references|â ]] |ConfRecord=6-1[[2005 Oklahoma vs. Texas football game#Notes and references|â ]] |HeadCoach=[[Bob Stoops]] |OffCoach=[[Chuck Long]] |DefCoach=Brent Venables |OScheme=Multiple/Northwestern Spread |DScheme=Multiple/4-2-5/4-3 |StadiumArena=[[Gaylord Family Oklahoma Memorial Stadium]] |BowlTourney= [[Holiday Bowl]] |BowlTourneyResult=Won 17-14 vs. [[Oregon Ducks]] }}
The '''2005 Oklahoma vs. Texas football game''', played October 8, 2005, was the 100th meeting between the [[University of Oklahoma]] and [[University of Texas at Austin|The University of Texas at Austin]] in a [[college football]] game. The annual game between the [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas Longhorns]] and the [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma Sooners]] is called the [[Red River Shootout]]. It is considered by college football coaches to be one of the three greatest rivalry games in college football,<ref name="coach-rivals"/> and ''[[Fox Sports (USA)|Fox Sports]]'' says the rivalry includes some of the most unusual traditions in the sport.<ref name="Traditions"/><ref name="Gcoach"/> The game often has conference or national title significance (as this game did) and the series is unusual in that it is played at a neutral site instead of the home teams' stadium.<ref name="Gcoach"/>
The [[2005 Texas Longhorn football team]] (variously "Texas" or "UT" or the "Horns") was coached by head football coach [[Mack Brown]] and led on the field by [[quarterback]] [[Vince Young]]. The [[2005 Oklahoma Sooners football team]] (variously "Oklahoma" or "OU") was coached by [[Bob Stoops]] with [[Rhett Bomar]] at quarterback. This was the fourth game of the [[2005 NCAA Division I-A football season|2005 season]] for both teams. Texas came into the game with a 4-0 record and a No.2 ranking. Oklahoma was 2-2 and unranked.<ref name="Texas Defeats Oklahoma"/> Both teams were 1-0 in conference play. Since the two teams are both in the South Division of the [[Big 12 Conference]], winning this game would be an important step towards winning the Division and possibly the Conference.<ref name="Gcoach"/> For Texas, a loss would likely eliminate hope of them playing in the [[NCAA Division I-A national football championship|BCS National Championship Game]].<ref name="Texas Defeats Oklahoma"/>
Prior to the game, UT was favored by 14 points.<ref name="pass credit"/> They took an early 7-point lead and led for the rest of the game.<ref name="Texas Defeats Oklahoma"/> Although the score was close for the first quarter, Texas eventually won the game by 33 points,<ref name="OU-box">{{cite web | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/000_stats/05/ut5.htm | title=Oklahoma vs Texas (Oct 08, 2005) | work=MackBrownTexasFootball | accessdate=2007-03-19}}</ref> tying the biggest margin of victory for the Longhorns (a 40-7 victory in 1941) in the 100-game history of the rivalry. For Mack Brown, beating Oklahoma for the first time in five years allowed him to "get the monkey off his back" and shed his reputation as a coach incapable of winning the most important games.<ref name="pass credit"/><ref name="road to Rose clear"/><ref name="TX-CU"/>
The stadium attendance was 75,452 people, and the game was televised over most of the United States on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]].<ref name="ABC coverage">{{cite news | url=http://espn-att.starwave.com/tvlistings/map/ncf/051008.gif | title=ABC College Football | publisher=ABC | accessdate=2007-04-16}}</ref> Texas' win kept them near the front of the national championship picture. They ultimately finished the season unbeaten, snaring the [[Big 12 Conference]] and [[NCAA]] championships. Oklahoma finished the season with eight wins and four losses and ranked No. 22 in the nation.
==The Red River Shootout== {{main|Red River Shootout}} The [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma Sooners]] and the [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas Longhorns]] are two of the most storied programs in college football.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.sportsnetwork.com/merge/tsnform.aspx?c=globe&page=cfoot/scores/live/pv14170.htm | title= (7) Texas (4-1) vs. (14) Oklahoma (3-1) | date=October 7, 2005 | accessdate=2007-04-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/okla-texas.html | title=OU-Texas Weekend | work= SoonerSports.com |publisher=[[University of Oklahoma|University of Oklahoma Athletic Department]] | accessdate=2007-08-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://proxy.espn.go.com/ncf/columns/story?columnist=schlabach_mark&id=2537618 | title=Bomar's dismissal levels Big 12 playing field | date=August 9, 2006 | accessdate=2007-04-17}}</ref><ref name="tickco.com">{{cite news | url=http://www.tickco.com/sports/NCAA_Football/ohio_state_football_tickets.htm | title=Ohio State Football Tickets | publisher=TickCo | accessdate=2007-04-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://friends.macjournals.com/mattd/bcswins2002 | title=The BCS wins after all | publisher=Life and Deatherage | accessdate=2007-04-12}}</ref><ref name="Top 5 teams">{{cite news | url=http://media.www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2005/09/07/Sports/Top-5.Teams.Prepare.For.Primetime-977296.shtml | title=Top 5 teams prepare for primetime | publisher=The Daily Texan | date=September 5, 2005 | accessdate=2007-04-12|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930220943/http://media.www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2005/09/07/Sports/Top-5.Teams.Prepare.For.Primetime-977296.shtml |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="Buckeyes welcome">{{cite news | url=http://ohiostatebuckeyes.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/090505aaa.html | title=Buckeyes Welcome Texas to Ohio Stadium | publisher=Ohio State University | date=September 5, 2005 | accessdate=2007-04-13}}</ref> Prior to 2005 each school had participated in college football for more than 100 years.<ref name="Top 5 teams"/> They are home to nationally-known traditions from the [[Sooner Schooner]] and the [[RUF/NEKS]] at Oklahoma to [[Bevo (mascot)|Bevo]] and the [[Hook 'em Horns]] of Texas.<ref name="Traditions">{{cite news | title=Traditions: Texas-Oklahoma | url=http://msn.foxsports.com/story?contentId=3062152&print=true | publisher=Fox Sports | accessdate=2007-04-17}}</ref> The annual OU/UT football game is considered to be one of the greatest rivalry games in all of college sports.<ref name="coach-rivals">{{cite news | url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/colleges/redrivershootout/texas/stories/100705dnspofbwnewrivalrylede.1c8619ce.html | title=UT-OU : Best Rivalry? | work=[[Dallas Morning News]] | author=Davis, Brian | date=2005-10-07 | accessdate=2006-07-11|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930031446/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/colleges/redrivershootout/texas/stories/100705dnspofbwnewrivalrylede.1c8619ce.html |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="Gcoach"/>
The 2005 matchup was officially called the Red River Rivalry,<ref name="SBC">{{cite web | url=http://www.sbc.com/gen/press-room?pid=4800&cdvn=news&newsarticleid=21762 | title=SBC Companies Extend Sponsorship with Universities of Oklahoma and Texas for the SBC Red River Rivalry | work=ATT.com | accessdate=2006-07-11}}</ref> but the game is better known by its traditional name, the [[Red River Shootout]].<ref name="Michigan-tradition">{{cite news | url=http://www.michigandaily.com/media/storage/paper851/news/2004/11/02/Opinioneditorials/From-The.Daily.Adhering.To.Tradition-1426377.shtml?norewrite200607111727&sourcedomain=www.michigandaily.com | title=From the Daily:Adhering to tradition - SBC Sponsor Threatened Game's Integrity | publisher=The Michigan Daily | date=2006-07-10 | accessdate=2006-07-11|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930201144/http://www.michigandaily.com/media/storage/paper851/news/2004/11/02/Opinioneditorials/From-The.Daily.Adhering.To.Tradition-1426377.shtml?norewrite200607111727&sourcedomain=www.michigandaily.com |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}} </ref><ref name="thirteen or less">{{cite news | url=http://www.google.com/search?q=cache:LDb5NWX9aLcJ:www.chron.com/cs/CDA/ssistory.mpl/sports/3305696+JOSEPH+DUARTE+Chronicle+%22political+correctness%22&hl=en&gl=us&ct=clnk&cd=1&client=firefox-a | title=Defense's goal is 13 points or less | publisher=Houston Chronicle | date=2005-08-11 | accessdate=2006-07-11}}</ref> It is played at a neutral site, the [[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]] stadium in [[Dallas, Texas]], amid the atmosphere of the [[Texas State Fair]] which is held adjacent to the Cotton Bowl.<ref name="news_record">{{cite web | url=http://www.newsrecord.org/media/storage/paper693/news/2003/11/19/Sports/Column.Rivalries.Spark.College.Football-693841.shtml?norewrite200606152025&sourcedomain=www.newsrecord.org | title=Column: Rivalries spark college football |work=The News Record | publisher=University of Cincinnati | accessdate=2006-06-15}}</ref> Dallas is approximately half the distance between the two school campuses, and the stadium is divided down the 50-yard line, with half of the stadium clad in the "crimson and cream" colors of Oklahoma, and the other half wearing the [[variations of orange#Burnt orange|burnt orange]] and white of Texas.<ref name="Traditions"/><ref name="OU game week">{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/doc_lib/2005_Oklahoma_notes.pdf | format = PDF | title=Game Week | publisher=MackBrownTexasFootball | accessdate=2006-12-14}}</ref> [[Red River Shootout trophies|Three rivalry trophies]] are presented to the winning of each year's contest.<ref name="Gcoach"/><ref name="victor">{{cite web |url=http://www.oudaily.com/vnews/display.v?TARGET=printable&article_id=3f84da355f862 |title=To the victor goes the trophy - OU and Texas will vie for the right to take the trophy home | work = OUDaily.com | accessdate = 2006-06-15 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070927065601/http://www.oudaily.com/vnews/display.v?TARGET=printable&article_id=3f84da355f862 |archivedate = September 27, 2007|deadurl=yes}} </ref> The anticipation for the 2005 meeting was especially keen since it marked the 100th Red River Shootout.<ref name="RRS-DMN">{{cite news | url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/colleges/redrivershootout/texas/vitindex.html | title=Red River Rivalry:Texas | work=[[Dallas Morning News]] | date=October 8, 2005 | accessdate=2006-07-30|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080201033103/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/colleges/redrivershootout/texas/vitindex.html |archivedate = February 01, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
The game typically has conference or even national significance. Since 1945, one or both of the two teams has been ranked among the top 25 teams in the nation coming into 60 out of 65 games. Prior to the 2005 game, Texas held an advantage in the all-time series 55-39-5, which included a 43-35-4 edge in Dallas, but Oklahoma had won five consecutive games, including the worst loss ever for a Texas team in the series.<ref name="Gcoach"/><ref name="Sooner-stats">{{cite web | url=http://soonerstats.com/football/series/details.cfm?OppID=7 | title=OU-Texas Football Series |publisher=SoonerStats.com| accessdate=2006-07-30}}</ref> That was the longest losing streak for the Longhorns going back to the 1950s and during those five years the Sooners had 189 points to 59 points by UT.<ref name="Texas Defeats Oklahoma">{{cite news | title=Texas Defeats Oklahoma at Cotton Bowl | url= http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/100805aaa.html|agency=Associated Press | format=reprint| date=2005-10-08| accessdate=2007-08-22}}</ref> Those five straight losses had helped build a reputation for Mack Brown that he was not capable of winning in so-called "Big Games".<ref name="Texas Defeats Oklahoma"/><ref name="road to Rose clear">{{cite news | url=http://media.www.michigandaily.com/media/storage/paper851/news/2005/10/13/Sports/Longhorns.Road.To.The.Rose.Bowl.Is.Clear-1432097.shtml?sourcedomain=www.michigandaily.com&MIIHost=media.collegepublisher.com | title=Longhorns' road to the Rose Bowl is clear | authors=Geise, John & Kia Hamadanch | publisher=The Michigan Daily | date=October 13, 2005 | accessdate=2007-01-17|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930201135/http://media.www.michigandaily.com/media/storage/paper851/news/2005/10/13/Sports/Longhorns.Road.To.The.Rose.Bowl.Is.Clear-1432097.shtml?sourcedomain=www.michigandaily.com&MIIHost=media.collegepublisher.com |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="MB-OSU">{{cite news | url=http://www.buckeyextra.com/?story=132929 | title=Transcript of Mack Brown's postgame news conference | publisher=BuckeyeXtra.com | date=September 11, 2005 | accessdate=2007-01-17}}</ref><ref name="USA-OSU">{{cite news | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/2005-09-09-whiteside_x.htm | title=Wuerffel says Katrina will not destroy ministry | publisher=USA Today | author=Whiteside, Kelly | date=September 9, 2005 | accessdate=2007-01-17}}</ref><ref name="coaching debate">{{cite news | url=http://www.coversexperts.com/includes/article_ce.aspx?ce=20087&ur=6367 | title=The Great Coaching Debate | author=Sevransky, Ted | publisher=Covers.experts | accessdate=2007-01-17|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071007022015/http://www.coversexperts.com/includes/article_ce.aspx?ce=20087&ur=6367 |archivedate = October 07, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="TOTK">{{cite news | url=http://sportsbytes.net/article.asp?articleid=75234 | title=Coach Catharsis | author=Flint, Ross | publisher=TOTK.com | date=January 5, 2006 | accessdate=2007-01-17|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070927045310/http://sportsbytes.net/article.asp?articleid=75234 |archivedate = September 27, 2007|deadurl=yes}} </ref> Four times during those five years, Texas' loss to Oklahoma was what prevented them from playing in the Big 12 Conference Championship Game.<ref name="full plate">{{cite news | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/columnist/weekendforecast/2005-10-05-column_x.htm | title=Full plate of Big 12, SEC showdowns worth feasting on | publisher=USA Today | author=Smith, Erick | date=October 5, 2005 |accessdate=2007-01-17}}</ref>
The 2005 game was the 100th meeting in the series and a special logo (above right) was created to commemorate the event. The game logo included both team logos as well as the logo of the sponsor for that game, SBC communications, as well as the number 100.
==Prior to the game== [[File:TX OU Red River Shootout in Cotton Bowl seen from fair grounds - with arrow showing 50 yard line.JPG|left|thumb|2006 Red River Shootout with yellow arrow indicating the 50 yard line]]
Oklahoma is the winningest program in what is widely considered the modern era of college football. OU has the most victories and best winning percentage of any team since the end of World War II. The Sooners have earned seven AP National Championships (1950, 1955, 1956, 1974, 1975, 1985, 2000) in that span and are recognized by the NCAA for 16 titles. They have been ranked first in the AP and BCS polls more than any other team, have been ranked in the top 5 of the AP and BCS polls more than any other team, and have scored more points than any other team in the modern era.<ref name="SoonerSports No 1">{{cite news | url=http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/archive/m-footbl-no1-program-modern-era.html | title=Sooners the No. 1 Program of the Modern Era| date= 2007-11-12 | work=SoonerSports.com |publisher=[[University of Oklahoma|University of Oklahoma Athletic Department]] | accessdate=2007-11-12}}</ref><ref name="SoonerSports Gameday">{{cite news | url=http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/100505aaa.html | title=Sooner Gameday Central - Texas | date=2005-10-01| work=SoonerSports.com |publisher=[[University of Oklahoma|University of Oklahoma Athletic Department]] | accessdate=2007-08-21}}</ref> Naturally, Oklahoma had high expectations for the year. Their pre-season ranking of No.7 in the nation and the fact they had made it to the national championship game [[Oklahoma Sooners football under Bob Stoops#2005|in both 2003 and 2004]] only served to support this assumption.<ref name="road to Rose clear"/>
One of the three most victorious programs in college football history as judged by either number of wins or winning percentage,<ref name="USA_Brown">{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/doc_lib/usatoday.com_%20brown_has_texas_savoring_possibilities.pdf | format = PDF | title=Brown has Texas savoring the possibilities | publisher=USA Today | author = Wieberg, Steve | date=December 2, 2005 | accessdate=2006-06-27}}</ref> the University of Texas has traditionally been considered among the elite of college football.<ref name="NCAA_tickets">{{cite web | url=http://www.ncaaticketsnow.com/texas-tickets.asp | title=2004-2005 NCAA football tickets | accessdate=2006-06-27}}</ref><ref name="Tarheel">{{cite news |publisher=The Daily Tarheel | author=Fitt, Aaron | url=http://www.dailytarheel.com/media/storage/paper885/news/2002/09/14/Sportsaturday/Its-Not.About.Mack-1349746.shtml?norewrite200606280132&sourcedomain=www.dailytarheel.com | title=It's not about Mack|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080213041712/http://www.dailytarheel.com/media/storage/paper885/news/2002/09/14/Sportsaturday/Its-Not.About.Mack-1349746.shtml?norewrite200606280132&sourcedomain=www.dailytarheel.com |archivedate = February 13, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> From 1936 to 2004, the team finished the season in the top ten 23 times, or one-third of the time, according to the [[Associated Press]]. The team that coach Mack Brown fielded in 2005 has been called one of the most memorable in college football history by ''College Football News''.<ref name="CCFN">{{cite news | author=Fiutak, Pete | url=http://www.collegefootballnews.com/Almanac/CFN_Formula/CFN_FormulaAllTime.htm |title=Formula and Calculations for All-Time Greatest Football Teams | publisher=College Football News | accessdate=2006-06-27 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060614161713/http://www.collegefootballnews.com/Almanac/CFN_Formula/CFN_FormulaAllTime.htm |archivedate = 2006-06-14}}</ref>
The 2005 UT team was attempting to follow on the success of the 2004 season, in which quarterback Vince Young led the team to Mack Brown's first [[Bowl Championship Series]] (BCS) game in the 2005 Rose Bowl and a top-5 finish in the polls. However, even that successful season was marred by a loss to Oklahoma, the fifth straight loss for the Horns. With the exception of [[Cedric Benson]], [[Derrick Johnson]], and [[Bo Scaife]], Texas returned most of their key players from 2004â2005, including [[redshirt (college sports)|redshirt]] junior quarterback Vince Young.
Texas was given a pre-season No. 2 ranking (behind defending National Champions [[University of Southern California]]) by ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' magazine and was also ranked second in the pre-season [[Associated Press Poll]] and ''[[USA Today]]'' [[Coaches Poll]].<ref name="Preseason consensus">{{cite web | url=http://preseason.stassen.com/consensus/2005.html#national | title=2005 Preseason Consensus | publisher=Stassen.com | accessdate=2006-07-24 }}</ref> This created anticipation that Texas might play for the national championship if they could win their road game against the [[2005 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State Buckeyes]]<ref name="play for">{{cite news | url=http://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/preview?gid=200509100033 | title=(2) Texas - (4) Ohio State | publisher=Yahoo.com | date=September 10, 2005 | accessdate=2007-01-17}}</ref> and if they could snap their five-game losing streak against the Sooners.<ref name="road to Rose clear"/>
For either team to play in the national title game, that team had to end up [[2005 NCAA Division I-A football rankings|ranked No. 1 or No. 2]] at the end of the regular season. Since the [[Bowl Championship Series]] was formed in 1998, 9 of the 14 teams were unbeaten going into the championship game.<ref name="on-the-line">{{cite news | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14687967 | title=Ohio State, Texas put BCS hopes on line - Nos. 1-, 2-ranked teams can't afford loss in big matchup Saturday | agency=Associated Press | publisher=MSNBC | date=September 8, 2006 | accessdate=2006-09-08}}</ref> The only time the national champion has not been unbeaten during that stretch was in 2003 when [[LSU Tigers football|LSU]] and [[University of Southern California|USC]] claimed a share of the title as each finished with one loss.<ref name="on-the-line"/><ref name="Tx-OSU-Preview">{{cite news | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14687408/ | title=Ohio St-Texas Preview | publisher=MSNBC | author=Einhorn, Justin | date=September 7, 2006 | accessdate=2006-09-07}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Ohio State tackle Kirk Barton would later say "Thereâll probably be two undefeated teams at the end of the road and if youâre not one of them youâre probably not going to be playing for the championship. So youâve got to treat every game like itâs the [[Super Bowl]]. You only get one opportunity."<ref name="on-the-line"/> {{see|2005 NCAA Division I-A football rankings}} {{see|2005 Texas Longhorn football team#Rankings}}
==First quarter== {{See also|American football positions|Glossary of American football}} Oklahoma won the [[coin flipping|coin toss]] and deferred to the second half. Texas used 5:52 worth of game clock to score on their first possession (12 plays, 82 yards) with a [[touchdown]] by [[Ramonce Taylor]].<ref name="OU-box"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics"/> It marked the first time Texas had taken a lead in the Red River Rivalry since 2002.<ref name="OU Game Notes">{{cite web | url=http://www.soonersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?ATCLID=201725 | title=Oklahoma Sooners - Game Notes | date=October 8, 2005 | accessdate=2007-04-18 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071007170003/http://www.soonersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?ATCLID=201725 |archivedate = 2007-10-07}}</ref> OU and UT traded [[Punt (football)|punts]] and then OU's [[Garrett Hartley]] scored a 52-yard [[Field goal (football)|field goal]] to make the score Oklahoma-3, Texas-7.<ref name="Texas Defeats Oklahoma"/><ref name="OU-box"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics"/> This was the longest field goal of Hartley's college career.<ref name="OU Game Notes"/> OU kicked off for a [[touchback]] and Texas started on their own 20. On the first play, tailback [[Selvin Young]] rushed over the right guard to the UT22 where OU's [[D.J. Wolfe]] forced a [[fumble]]; the ball was recovered by OU's [[Zach Latimer]] at the UT26. The Sooners ran two [[rushing]] plays to acquire a first down at the fifteen. A short run-play, a short [[forward pass|pass]] play, and an [[incomplete pass]] followed to set up fourth and four from the 9. OU elected for field goal making the score 6-7 in favor of the Horns. OU kicked off for another touchback so Texas again started at their 20.<ref name="OU-box"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics"/> The first play was a hand off to [[Jamaal Charles]] and he ran it 80 yards for a touchdown.<ref name="Texas Defeats Oklahoma"/><ref name="OU-box"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics"/> The Sooners punted on their next possession, and the first quarter ended with Texas on their own 23-yard-line and an eight-point lead.<ref name="OU-box"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics">{{cite web | url=http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/stats/2005-2006/texas.html | title=Texas 45, Oklahoma 12 (Oct 08, 2005) | work=SoonerSports.com | publisher=[[University of Oklahoma|University of Oklahoma Athletic Department]]| date=2005-10-08| accessdate=2007-08-21}}</ref>
==Second quarter== Texas was not able to score on that drive and they punted the ball to Oklahoma, who began their drive on their 32-yard line. It was the first of four consecutive combined punts for the two teams and during this time the clock wound down to 6:54 remaining in the first half. Texas snapped the scoring drought with an eight play, 32-yard drive that culminated in a 38-yard field goal. The Sooners punted on their next possession, giving the ball to UT on their 30-yard line with 0:55 remaining. Vince Young rushed for eleven yards and a first down, but the next play was called back because of a Longhorn penalty. Young then completed a pass to Billy Pitman who ran 64 yards along the left sideline for a touchdown with 0:17 in the half. The extra point made the score OU-6, UT-24 and Oklahoma [[Glossary of American football#T|took a knee]] to end the half.<ref name="OU-box"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics"/>
==Third quarter== The Longhorns scored once in the third quarter as Young threw a 27-yard pass to Billy Pittman to increase the Longhorn lead to 25 points.<ref name="OU-box"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics"/> As stated by the Associated Press, "the rout was on".<ref name="Texas Defeats Oklahoma"/> The Sooners only got within UT territory once, and that drive ended abruptly when [[Michael Huff]] intercepted [[Rhett Bomar]]'s pass at the UT36.<ref name="OU-box"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics"/> This was the first [[interception]] for Bomar in 73 attempts.<ref name="OU Game Notes"/> As the third quarter ended, UT had just gained a first down at the OU37.<ref name="OU-box"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics"/>
==Fourth quarter== [[File:2005 Red River Shootout cropped.jpg|right|thumb|2005 Red River Shootout - OU bench and Texas flags]] UT did score a touchdown on that drive to go ahead 38-6. The kickoff by UT's [[Greg Johnson]] went 54 yards to the OU 11 where [[Lendy Holmes]] caught the ball and made a 21-yard return to the OU 32. UT committed two penalties on the play: a face mask penalty for 15 yards and a personal foul, also for 15 yards. This gave the Sooners their best starting field position of the day: 1st and 10, OU ball on the UT 38. From there, OU punched in the touchdown with a five-play series culminating in a 15-yard pass to [[Joe Jon Finley]]. Texas ended their next series by punting. OU drove to the Texas 23 when Brian Robison sacked Bomar and forced a fumble. The ball was picked up by UT's [[Rodrique Wright]], who ran 67 yards for a touchdown with 7:41 left in the game. For the second time in a row, the Sooners combined a kick-off return with a penalty against Texas. This time, Lendy Holmes fielded the ball at the OU 17 and returned it 29 yards to the OU 46. The penalty was another personal foul against Texas, which move the ball to the UT 39. The Texas defense stopped Oklahoma and Garrett Hartley came in to attempt a 41-yard field goal but it went wide right and UT took over at its own 24 with 2:21 remaining and a 45-12 lead. Texas ran three running plays and then took a knee to [[Running out the clock|run out the clock]].<ref name="OU-box"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics"/>
==Analysis== Prior to the game, the Longhorns were ranked second by the Associated Press, and the Sooners were unranked for the first time since 1999, which was also Texas's last victory over OU. Texas was favored by 14 points;<ref name="pass credit"/> they ended up winning the game by 33 points,<ref name="OU-box"/> tying the biggest margin of victory for the Longhorns (a 40-7 victory in 1941) in the 100-game history of the rivalry. The game also marked the sixth time the Longhorns have entered the contest ranked second nationally, and they have won all six times.<ref name="OU game week"/> With the win, Texas started their season 5-0 for the first time since 1983.<ref name="all-time results">{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=36&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=1349&change_well_id=2 | title=All-Time Results | work=MackBrownTexasFootball | date=December 30, 2006 | accessdate=2007-03-30}}</ref> That also happened to be the last time UT had legitimate national title hopes, ending the regular season 11-0 before losing to [[Georgia Bulldogs|Georgia]] in the [[Cotton Bowl Classic]] [[bowl game|game]]. For Mack Brown, beating Oklahoma for the first time in five years allowed him to "get the monkey off his back" and shed his reputation as a coach incapable of winning the most important games.<ref name="pass credit">{{cite news | url=http://media.www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2005/10/07/Sports/Brown.Ready.To.Pass.Credit.Rather.Than.Take.Blame-1013647.shtml?sourcedomain=www.dailytexanonline.com&MIIHost=media.collegepublisher.com | title=Brown ready to pass credit rather than take blame - Players insist Brown shoulders too much burden for OU losses | author=Veyhl, Jack | work=[[The Daily Texan]] | date=October 7, 2005 | accessdate=2007-01-17|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930201225/http://media.www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2005/10/07/Sports/Brown.Ready.To.Pass.Credit.Rather.Than.Take.Blame-1013647.shtml?sourcedomain=www.dailytexanonline.com&MIIHost=media.collegepublisher.com |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="road to Rose clear"/><ref name="TX-CU">{{cite news | url=http://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/preview?gid=200510150083 | title=(24) Colorado - (2) Texas | publisher=yahoo.com | date=October 15, 2005 | accessdate=2007-01-17}}</ref>
By breaking the string of five consecutive losses to Oklahoma, Longhorn coach [[Mack Brown]] preserved the Longhorns's [[NCAA Division I-A national football champions|National Championship]] hopes. UT Freshman [[running back]] [[Jamaal Charles]] set a record for rushing yards by a Texas freshman in the series. With his 80-yard scamper, Charles also had the longest touchdown from scrimmage by a Texas running back in the series. Vince Young completed 14 out of 27 passes for 241 yards and also ran for 45 yards.<ref name="Texas Defeats Oklahoma"/><ref name="Oklahoma game statistics"/>
As a result of the loss, Oklahoma's record changed to 39-56-5 all-time in the Red River Rivalry,<ref name="Gcoach">{{cite news | url=http://community.foxsports.com/blogs/gcoach/2006/10/02/College_Football_Rivalries_Red_River_Shootout | title=College Football Rivalries - Red River Shootout | date=October 2, 2006 | publisher=[[Fox Sports (USA)|Fox Sports]] | accessdate=2007-04-19|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930043944/http://community.foxsports.com/blogs/gcoach/2006/10/02/College_Football_Rivalries_Red_River_Shootout |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=36&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=298&change_well_id=2 | title=All-time records vs opponents | work=MackBrownTexasFootball | date=December 30, 2006 | accessdate=2007-04-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/colleges/redrivershootout/history/scores.html | title=Texas-Oklahoma series scores - A list of the scores of the annual Texas-Oklahoma football game (Texas leads series 57-39-5) | work=[[Dallas Morning News]] | date=April 19, 2007 | accessdate=2007-04-19|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080616050855/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/colleges/redrivershootout/history/scores.html |archivedate = June 16, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> while Bob Stoopsâ is 5-2 against the Longhorns and 21-6 vs. ranked opponents.<ref name="OU Game Notes"/>
==After the game== As had occurred the two seasons prior when Oklahoma won the Red River Shootout en-route to a national title game, the road to the 2005 National Championship game went through Dallas. This time it was Texas who eventually finished the [[2005 NCAA Division I-A football season|season of 2005-2006]] as the only undefeated team, winning both the [[Big 12 Conference]] championship<ref name="Texas overpowers">{{cite news | title=Texas Overpowers Colorado To Win Big 12 football Championship | url=http://www.big12sports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/120305aaa.html | publisher=[[Big 12 Conference]] | date=December 3, 2005 | accessdate=2006-12-12 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061109193349/http://www.big12sports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/120305aaa.html |archivedate = 2006-11-09}}</ref> and the [[NCAA Division I-A national football championship|National Championship]].<ref name="Texas beats USC">{{cite news | url=http://www.big12sports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/010506aaa.html | title=Texas Wins National Championship, Beats USC 41-38 - Vince Young scrambles for an 8-yard touchdown on fourth down with 19 seconds left to take lead. | publisher=[[Big 12 Conference]] | date=January 4, 2006 | accessdate=2006-12-12 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061106174905/http://www.big12sports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/010506aaa.html |archivedate = 2006-11-06}}</ref>
The Longhorns' penultimate victory of the season, in the [[Big 12 Football Championship Game|Big 12 Championship Game]], featured the biggest margin of victory in the history of that contest. Their ultimate victory in the 2006 [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] against the [[University of Southern California]] [[2005 USC Trojans football team|Trojans]] for the national championship, as well as their overall season, have both been cited as standing among the greatest performances in college football history by publications such as ''[[College Football News]]'',<ref name="CCFN"/><ref name="10 greatest">{{cite news | url=http://cfn.scout.com/2/564658.html | title=Tuesday Question - Ten Greatest Bowl Games | date=September 5, 2006 | publisher=College Football News | author=Cirminiello, Richard and Harris, John | accessdate=2006-12-13}}</ref><ref name="CFB best ever">{{cite news | author=Fiutak, Pete | url=http://www.collegefootballnews.com/2006/TQ/Rose_Best.htm | title=Was the 2006 Rose Bowl the best college football game ever? | publisher=College Football News | date=January 10, 2006 | accessdate=2006-10-20 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060616201851/http://www.collegefootballnews.com/2006/TQ/Rose_Best.htm |archivedate = 2006-06-16}}</ref> the ''[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]'',<ref name="grand">{{cite news | last=Bisher| first=Furman| authorlink= Furman Bisher |url=http://www.ajc.com/blogs/content/shared-blogs/ajc/sportscolumns/entries/2006/01/06/rose_bowl_a_gra.html | title=BCS enjoys 'grand cresendo' | work=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]| date=2006-01-06 | accessdate=2006-12-12}}</ref> ''Scout.com'',<ref name="Scouts best">{{cite news | url=http://louisianastate.scout.com/2/596414.html | title=Is the bloom off the Rose? | author=Defresne, Chris | publisher=Scouts.com | date=December 1, 2006 | accessdate=2006-12-13}}</ref> and ''[[Sports Illustrated]]''.<ref name="YoungNite">{{cite news | author=Murphy, Austin | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/preview/siexclusive/2006/pr/subs/siexclusive/01/05/cf.bcs0109/ | title=The Night is Young's | work=[[Sports Illustrated]] | date=January 5, 2006 | accessdate=2006-07-30}}</ref> The Longhorns and the Trojans were together awarded the 2006 [[ESPY Award]] by [[ESPN]] for the "Best Game" in any sport.<ref name="TexasTrifecta">Fisher, Gerren LaQuint{{Cite news | url=http://www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2006/07/14/Sports/Texas.Snags.Espy.Trifecta-2131713.shtml?norewrite200607252146&sourcedomain=www.dailytexanonline.com | title=Texas snags ESPY trifecta - 2006 Rose Bowl voted Best Game of the year, Vince gets Best Championship Performance | work=[[The Daily Texan]] | date=July 14, 2006 | accessdate=2006-07-25 | author=Fisher, Gerren LaQuint|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070928003440/http://www.dailytexanonline.com/media/storage/paper410/news/2006/07/14/Sports/Texas.Snags.Espy.Trifecta-2131713.shtml?norewrite200607252146&sourcedomain=www.dailytexanonline.com |archivedate = September 28, 2007|deadurl=yes}} </ref> The Longhorns finished the season as the only unbeaten team, with 13 wins and zero losses overall.<ref name="Win/Loss>College football team records are conventionally expressed in number of wins/losses. 13-0 means 13 wins and zero losses.</ref><ref name="Big12_standings">{{cite web | url = http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/doc_lib/06_records_3_big12.pdf | format = PDF | title=All Time Big-12 Standings | work = MackBrownTexasFootball.com | accessdate=2006-06-26}}</ref>
The season gave Texas its second Big 12 football championship<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/doc_lib/06_records_3_big12.pdf | format = PDF | title=All Time Big-12 Standings | work=MackBrownTexasFootball.com | accessdate=2006-06-26}}</ref> (27 conference championships total, including 25 in the [[Southwest Conference]]),<ref name="SWC_standings">{{cite web | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/doc_lib/06_records_3_swc.pdf | format = PDF | title=All Time SWC Standings | work=MackBrownTexasFootball.com | accessdate=2006-06-26}}</ref> and fourth consensus national championship in football.<ref name="NCAA_Championship_list">{{cite web | url=http://www.ncaa.org/champadmin/ia_football_past_champs.html | title=Past Division I-A Football National Champions | work=NCAA.org | accessdate=2006-06-27 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060613014918/http://www.ncaa.org/champadmin/ia_football_past_champs.html |archivedate = 2006-06-13}}</ref> It was the ninth [[List of undefeated Division I-A football teams|perfect season]] in the history of Longhorn football.<ref name="All time results">{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=36&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=1349&change_well_id=2 | title=University of Texas - all time records | publisher=MackBrownTexasFootball.com | accessdate=2006-12-05}}</ref>
UT set numerous school and [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] records, including most points scored in a season (652). After the season ended, six Longhorns from this championship team were selected by [[National Football League|professional football teams]] in the [[2006 NFL Draft]].<ref name="NFL-draft">{{cite web | url=http://nfl.com/draft/drafttracker/school/TX | title=Draft Tracker - Texas | work=NFL.com - Official website of the NFL | date=April 30, 2006 | accessdate=2006-07-27 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060708171702/http://www.nfl.com/draft/drafttracker/school/TX |archivedate = 2006-07-08}}</ref> With Texas going on to [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]] to cap the 2005 season by playing for a national title, four of the last six Red River Shootouts have featured a team that went on to play in the Bowl Championship Series National Championship Game (2000, 2003-5).<ref name="Sooner-stats"/>
Just prior to the start of [[2006 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma's 2006 season]], [[Rhett Bomar]] was kicked off the team for accepting improper cash contributions. On July 11, 2007, the [[NCAA]] announced a finding of "failure to monitor" the employment of student athletes and handed out penalties. These included a verdict that all wins from the 2005 OU season were vacated, changing the team's record from 8-4 to 0-4 for that year.<ref>{{cite news | title=NCAA: OU must forfeit 2005 wins | url=http://newsok.com/article/3081227 | publisher=NewsOk.com | date=2007-07-11 | accessdate=2007-07-11 }}</ref> The University of Oklahoma has announced that it will appeal the finding and the vacation of the wins from the 2005 season.<ref>{{cite web | title=OU's response to the NCAA sanctions | url=http://newsok.com/article/3081535 | publisher=NewsOK.com | date=2007-07-12 | accessdate=2007-07-13}}</ref>
==Notes and references== â Oklahoma was later made to vacate their wins from the 2005 season due to violations of NCAA regulations regarding receiving extra compensation. {{Reflist|2}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=40&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=1959&change_well_id=2 | title=Official website of UT football - 2005 National Champions | accessdate=2006-07-30}} * {{cite web | title=2005 Bowl Championship Series Standings | url=http://www.bcsfootball.org/files/bcs-2005.pdf | format = PDF | publisher = The National Football Foundation & College Hall of Fame, Inc | accessdate=2006-07-30 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060515083305/http://www.bcsfootball.org/files/bcs-2005.pdf |archivedate = 2006-05-15}} * {{cite web | url=http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/100805aaa.html | title=Official website of OU football - Game Day - October 8, 2005 | accessdate=2007-08-22}} * {{cite web | title=2005 Bowl Championship Series Standings | url=http://www.bcsfootball.org/files/bcs-2005.pdf | publisher=The National Football Foundation & College Hall of Fame, Inc | accessdate=2006-07-20 | format=PDF |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060515083305/http://www.bcsfootball.org/files/bcs-2005.pdf |archivedate = 2006-05-15}} * {{cite web | title=Client News | publisher=Harris Interactive | url=http://www.harrisinteractive.com/news/bcspoll.asp | accessdate=2006-07-20 }} * {{cite web | title=Final Dec. 4th Rankings from the Harris Interactive College Football Poll | publisher=Harris Interactive | url=http://www.harrisinteractive.com/news/newsletters/bcsnews/BCS_Dec_4_2005.pdf | accessdate=2006-07-20 | format=PDF }} * {{cite web | url=http://preseason.stassen.com/consensus/2005.html | title=2005 Preseason Consensus | publisher=Stassen.com | accessdate=2006-07-21 }} * {{cite web | url=http://www.bcsfootball.org/index2.cfm?page=standings | title=BCS Standings | publisher=BCSfootball.org | accessdate=2006-07-31 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060629150146/http://www.bcsfootball.org/index2.cfm?page=standings |archivedate = 2006-06-29}}
